data.text: Should I Carry Spare Spokes when Bikepacking?

Silly question: do you carry spare spokes when bikepacking? I have DT Swiss G1800 wheels and just watched an how-to-replace video.....not 100% sure I'd be able to replace a spoke with all the tools, nevermind on the trail. What would be the issue with breaking a spoke while bikepacking? Would it be a journey-ending accident or more a "proceed with caution" thing? Do I need to get some spare spokes?

You should be able to get to a bike shop if you are careful. Sometimes you might need to tape the broken spoke to an adjacent one to stop it flapping around, so make sure you carry tape. I've only had one - from hanging my bike up by the front wheel on a train. Most of the people I have seen with broken spokes have been overweight men riding over loaded bikes ;)
data.author: Bridget McGill

data.text: I'm not overweight (well...I am according to the BMI but who isn't) but still a pretty heavy guy and when you add bags and my clumsiness to it.... basically an accident waiting to happen

Replacing spokes is easy, the only tool required is a spoke-key, just make sure the spare spokes you have are the correct length for your wheels.

data.author: Mike Bell

data.text: It depends, if you have low spoke wheels (24h) then breaking a spoke can be critical, but on a 32 or 36h wheel its less of an issue. Spokes are very light and easily taped to the frame or rack. If you have straight pull or bladed spokes they can be next to impossible to source at your LBS, but if you have J bend spokes they are reasonably easy to source.

data.text: It depends on the wheel and the weight you are carrying how serious a broken spike is. Lower spike counts can cause the rim to go out far enough to rub the frame. I take spare spokes as a shop may not carrying the correct lengths. I also carry a fibrefix spike for emergencies. Minimum weight you hope you never need but could save your ride.
data.author: Steve Coombs

data.text: I have limped back to the train station by overtightening the spokes around in and loosening the brake to eliminate rub. Not ideal. The reason to carry spokes in a long tour isn't so you can replace them. It's so the bike shop you find can replace them. I've never had a 36 spoke wheel so that could tolerate it but a broken spoke = stop and try to get it fixed. It will stress the others and you really don't want to be middle of nowhere when the second one goes.

data.text: I often carry 3 on a long trip - just dropped in the bottom of the frame bag they don't take up much space, but I don't recall ever having to use them. Replacing the fronts isn't too difficult, but the rear drive side usually requires the cassette to be removed and I don't carry the tool to do that. Probably the flexible emergency spokes would be better.
